author: stockpikr
body:
*This is a large shift for UK telecoms, Erickson, Samsung, Nokia, and Qualcomm. These companies will have until 2027 to* ***remove and replace*** *all 5g transmission equipment.*

FYI, Erickson, Samsung, Nokia are competitors to Huawei and use no Huawei equipment. Qualcomm sells chipsets to Huawei for use in their phones and buy nothing from Huawei.

author: LovableContrarian
body:
Bruh, it's based on future expectations.

AMD is grabbing market share like a hungry slut (not just in consumer PCs but also in consoles, enterprise, servers, etc), and INTC just continues to fuck up everything. It's honestly sort of amazing how many mistakes Intel has made in the past year or so, and they are legitimately at risk of becoming completely uncompetitive.

They basically lost 100% of the enthusiast/custom PC market overnight, and most of their revenue now comes from contracts with Dell, Lenovo, Apple, etc for desktop and notebook CPUs (and a few other random components, like wifi and Bluetooth cards). And, these companies will almost definitely be looking to AMD, as Intel's 7nm chips aren't expected to be available until *at least* 2022, and AMD is already mass-producing. Depending on how hard these companies ditch Intel, it could be an actual death blow. 

And that doesn't even bring up the issue that things are shifting more and more to mobile platforms, where Intel completely failed. Companies like Apple, Samsung, and Qualcomm absolutely dominate in the mobile SoC sector and managed to castrate a titan when Intel attempted to enter that market and failed miserably. 

It's bad news all around. 

Does that mean they can't come back? No. Of course they can. But the concerns are real.

What other major stocks have you seen recently crash 13% on earnings then just... Stay there? Flat? We are in the most legendary dip-buying market of all time, where almost any dip will be bought without any logic, and yet no one would touch INTC, which is one of the biggest tech companies in the world.

It's a bit concerning.

Your DD is basically "bruh, it's Intel. And they made a lot of money in 2019." But that's frankly just not very good DD my friend.

author: daaabears1
body:
This is what I did: I started with YouTube to learn exactly what 5G is, how it works differently compared to 4G and how absolutely life changing 5G will be compared to 4G. We’re talking self driving cars, delivery drones, and doctors in New York performing surgery on soldiers in Afghanistan in a tent. 

From there you have the companies that make the actually radio transmission device like Nokia and Ericsson (both very reasonably priced). Those devices have to go somewhere so you put them on a tower owned by AMT and CCI (crown castle, not carnival cruise line). Those companies make money renting the towers to the service providers. Then you have the companies that make the chips that go into those devices, the chips that go into cell phones, drones and the internet of things (NVDA, INTC, MRVL, QCOM, etc.). Then there are the companies that make the devices we buy to connect us to 5G (Apple, amazon, google, Tesla). Finally there are the service providers like Verizon att and t mobile that connect our devices to the 5G network. 

I suggest starting at YouTube. There are videos that explain what each company does and their role in the 5G network.

However, I wanted ALL of the companies with not a lot of money so I went after the 5G ETF (ticker: FIVG).

author: aditenz716
body:
It's the busiest week of second-quarter earnings season, with 171 S&P 500 companies scheduled to report.  

 Monday 7/27

F5 Networks , Hasbro , and SAP report quarterly results.

The Census Bureau releases the Durable Goods report for June. Expectations are for a 5.5% rise in new orders for durable manufactured goods, to $205 billion, after a 15.7% jump in May.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas reports its Texas Manufacturing Outlook survey for July. Economists forecast a reading of just above zero, continuing the index's rebound from records lows in March and April.

Tuesday 7/28

3M , Advanced Micro Devices , Altria Group , Amgen , eBay , McDonald's , MSCI , Mondelez International , Pfizer , Raytheon Technologies , S&P Global , Starbucks , and Visa report earnings.

The Conference Board releases its Consumer Confidence Index for June. Consensus estimate is for a 95.5 reading, slightly below May's 98.1.

Wednesday 7/29

The Federal Open Market Committee announces its monetary policy decision. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates near zero through 2022.

Boeing , Crown Castle International , Facebook , General Electric , Norfolk Southern , PayPal Holdings , Qualcomm , Sanofi , and Shopify report quarterly results.

The National Association of Realtors releases its Pending Home Sales Index for June. The index is seen rising 5.4% to a 105 reading, after a record spike of 44.3% in May.

Thursday 7/30

Alphabet , Amazon.com , American Tower , Apple , Comcast , ConocoPhillips , Electronic Arts , Eli Lilly , Ford Motor , Gilead Sciences , Moody's , Newmont , Northrop Grumman , Procter & Gamble , and United Parcel Service hold conference calls to discuss earnings.

The Bureau of Economic Analysis reports gross domestic product for the second quarter. Consensus estimate is for a decline of 34%, after a 5% fall in the first quarter. The largest quarterly drop recorded was 10% for the first three months of 1958. The BEA's release will probably confirm the end of the longest economic expansion in U.S. history, which began in June of 2009.

Friday 7/31

AbbVie , Caterpillar , Charter Communications , Chevron , Colgate-Palmolive , Exxon Mobil , Merck , Phillips 66 , and Under Armour report earnings.

The Institute for Supply Management releases its Chicago Purchasing Manager Index for July. Economists forecast a 42 reading, above June's 36.6 but still below the expansionary level of 50, which the index hasn't surpassed since last summer.

The BEA reports personal income and spending for June. Expectations for a 3% decline in income and a 6% jump in spending. This compares with a 4.2% drop and a 8.2% gain, respectively, in May.

&#x200B;

\-Barrons

author: ixamnis
body:
**RICK** \- Not fond of this one. In the current environment, I see no upside.  

Recognia has detected a "Head and Shoulders Top" chart pattern formed on RCI Hospitality Holdings Inc (RICK on NASDAQ). This bearish signal indicates that the price may fall from the close of 12.63 to the range of 7.25 - 8.25. The pattern formed over 24 days which is roughly the period of time in which the target price range may be achieved.

RCI Hospitality Holdings Inc has a current support price of 11.03 and a resistance level of 15.32.

A Head and Shoulders Top is considered a bearish signal. It indicates a possible reversal of the current uptrend to a new downtrend. A perfect example of the pattern has three sharp high points, the middle one being the highest, created by three successive rallies in the price of the financial instrument. The technical event occurs when the resistance marked by the neckline is "broken", thereby confirming the pattern.

**NCLH** \- It could be some time before you see returns on this one. Of all the cruise lines this one is probably in the best shape, financially. Long term hold, but be cautious.

**MGM** \- Another high risk stock. Again, this will likely come back in the long term, but I think you could do better with a solid tech stock or ETF in its place.

**DKNG** \- Probably overpriced, currently, but a decent long term pick.

**QCOM** \- solid company, great potential for both short term and long term. Buy lots of this one. Price target is $103; buy for under $90 if possible.

**TMUS** \- May struggle a bit in the next few weeks, but this is a solid pick. Might be a bit overpriced at the moment, but I think it will climb to $120 by the end of the year. Great long-term stock.

**ETSY** \- I think this is a decent pick, but it may be overbought at the moment. See if it dips, and buy the dip.

**SQ** \- I really like this company and this stock; but, again, I'm concerned that it may be overpriced. I'd watch for a dip, and buy then.

**BA** \- This one could be a good mid-term swing play. The MAX will be re-certified, and when that happens, I think the stock will pop. That said, the market for new jets may take years to reach the levels it was at a year ago. Buy, watch for the pop up, then sell.

(Just my opinion. I own shares of NCLH, MGM and TMUS)

author: time_to_nuke_china
body:
There are safety considerations with electromagnetic (EM) radiation.  Visible light, radiowaves, x-rays, etc are some of the bands on the complete spectrum of frequencies.  
   
[There are ionising and non-ionising bands as per this chart.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/375/cpsprodpb/2682/production/_107885890_5ggraphic-nc.png)  
  
For ionising radiation like x-rays we have to limit exposure because it is harming our cells' dna. For non-ionising radiation we have to limit exposure because body tissue heats up when it absorbs them.  
  
Consider sunlight, which is a broad band of EM. We can feel infrared heating us up but we can't feel the UV burning us.  
  
Well, [5G is going to use frequencies up to about 100GHz](https://photos5.appleinsider.com/gallery/30805-50906-An-illustration-of-the-areas-of-spectrum-5G-could-operate-within-via-Qualcomm-xl.jpg) which is much lower frequency band than sunlight and is not ionising radiation.  
  
5G is actually using microwaves so you know it can cook your flesh, except the power output of your phone's radio is kept well under the safe limits. The phone towers are a higher power output but the inverse square law means the receive level is quite low by the time it gets to you, and because of the number of mobile users, 5G towers and 4G towers are very close together transmitting on low power because that gives a cleaner signal and more data throughput.  
  
Finally I will quote the safe limit of 100GHz microwave output. [This NIH page mentions 10 Watts per square meter and 0.08 Watts per Kg.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6765906/) A 5G phone will never get anywhere near that and the tower signal will be received by the antenna at about 0.0000001 Watts  and I would guess that your body would absorb about 1 milliWatt max from the tower. 
  
So because we have blood and sweat cooling us down, the tiny bit of heat is no issue. We're talking milliwatts total, compared to   sunlight which is about 1000W of radiation per square meter and some of that is ionising, unlike 5G. And even sunlight isn't too bad in moderation but 5G is fine as a low level background signal. Actually if you look on a spectrum analyser... there is a noise floor at 100GHz with signals here and there anyway.  
  
I hope that puts it into perspective... 5G is basically low power warm radiation and doesn't modify DNA (doesn't cause cancer). And it can't cook you because the power output is low, like TV and FM signals. It is like TV and radio signals but a higher band and with a much more efficient modulation scheme for data throughput.  
  
Thanks for listening to my TED Talk.

author: Xbsnguy
body:
Looks like your portfolio is geared towards a 5G play. Unfortunately telecom giants like AT&T and others like Nokia don't have volatile enough price action to really justify options, nevermind tying down large amounts of capital in leaps. If you want to play 5G, your best bet IMO is Qualcomm, but they've already benefited from the 5G pump.

With respect to your ALLY puts, this is misstimed. Ally is on the uptrend. If you want to short then wait for it to reverse, but be ready to close out when the market decides it's time to reverse yet again. Maybe they'll actually announce bankruptcy by winter/late fall, and your puts will print bigly, but I'm personally not a fan of taking contrarian positions to what the market wants to do.

You can either (1) close your positions and open new ones in stocks that will actually move or (2) leg into spreads to credit yourself some of the losses back and hold until expiry.

Personally, it's going to suck, but I think you should close.

author: ElectronF
body:
Nvidia has peaked.  They got no where to go.  The only company they could get to use nvidia chips for anything, but their own products was nintendo, and they had to sell them at cost to nintendo to make it happen.  All nvidia has is rasing prices on consumer graphics cards and that will run out of steam eventually.

Comma.ai developed a self driving camera system with nvidia chips back in 2017-2018, but then the nvidia exec product developer got fired and replaced.  The new one refused to sell chips at a fair market rate and demanded they buy entire mini-pc boards at 5 times the price, not just the chips.  Comma wasted $100k in r&d developing a product they no longer had chips for. Now george hotz praises qualcomm, not for being cheap(gotta buy in larger batches), but for being consistent and reliable as a chip source so they can actually design a product around a chip and not get screwed.

tl;dr nvidia is too expensive for anyone to use their chips, not because the chips are expensive to make, but because they have crappy pricing and don't guarantee supply unless you are a huge company.

author: SwordfshII
body:
Two choices

1. Buy back at a loss
2. Let it exercise. Sell puts on the stock. Collect premium and eventually buy back in.

I made it well on QCOM. It usually runs in the $87-$91 range. Bought in at 87, sold $91 calls just recently exercised, now selling $87 puts.

author: nduxx
body:
1. INTC is getting its ass eaten on their own instruction set by AMD. Shit they wouldn't even have x86_64 if it weren't for AMD way back when.

2. INTC completely missed the mobile ship, conceded all gains to ARMH, AAPL, TSMC, NVDA, QCOM and whoever else.

3. INTC completely missed the GPU ship, conceded all gains to NVDA.

There's no bull case for this company. They're basically legacy crap the way IBM is, and yesterday they made it official.

author: finvesturself
body:
IMO, they will announce a target soon. 

Here's why :

Mr. Paulson is Vice President of Product Management at Qualcomm (A powerhouse of a company, and a great 5G play in itself). This alone tells me they probably have had a target before inception. Why? He has a full time dedicated career with a full plate. A man in that position is highly unlikely to undertake such a large endeavor on the possibility of acquiring a deal. Given his position and connections,  It is far more likely that he stumbled across an amazing opportunity or was approached by one. After consultation and/or careful deliberation, starting a SPAC was the fastest way to raise money and get this target to market. Given his background and ties I would also conclude that the target company will be in INDIA, which by the way has been making leaps and bounds in network expansion. IMO, they are hammering out the terms with the target now.  5G has already begun its rollout. So, it is in their best interest to announce sooner rather than later.
